Posts.Title: GOOD NEWS...IT CAN BE BEAT

Posts.Content: I have but one comment. Get out of town! They tried to kill me more than once here. I drive, or am driven to be more accurate, 3 hours away to see my beloved breast surgeon. They do a mammagram and if anything seems at all unclear they do the sonagram. It is very unfortunate, but to be treated well, we usually have to travel to where we can get the best. Once a year, she does a PET scan. But then, I have a long history. I have learned how to stand up to the medical establishment. At least that is one thing that has come from cancer. I a stronger. or bi_ _ _ er. Depending on ones viewpoint. Hugs, Di

Posts.Content:
Hello Donna,
I had a recurrence five, almost six years ago now. I was told by some that they would just try to prolong my life a little while. I am truly blessed. I know that there are many people who have a recurrence and it never comes back again. This is the place to be, a place of love, encouragement and information. I had never heard of the CEA test. I do know that new things come out all of the time. I too was in a clinical trial 5 years ago that has been on the news lately as working. When I was diagnosed the first time it didn't exist. Most of our new drugs didn't. Herceptin had just come out and it was by lottery. Do you all remember that?? Good wished to you Donna, Hugs, 
DiVanDyke

Posts.Title: Advice for callback mammogram etc

Posts.Content: Thanks girls. I know you aren't trying to scare me Bev, I want to know what I might be dealing with. Thanks. Can you tell me what a colposopie is? I think I might have had one before. They did a test after a bad pap test and then they did a cone procedure to take out all of the cells around it so that I could finish the school year before the hysterectomy. Major question? Does it hurt? Should I take a pain pill before I go? The other test I had did not hurt. I always took pain pills at Barnes during radiation since I was tied to a stake, or something twice a week so I didn't move during radiation and hyperthermia. It was just hard to stay in that position that long. I would have a hard time on survivor. Thanks for letting me know that you've had abnormals and they were OK.The nurse said that sometimes they are abnormal after having had radiation. I hope you are fine. Lots of love and hugs, Di
Posts.Title: Health failing and possible new cancer question ??????????

Posts.Content:
Thanks Bev, I'll definately ask. Hi to you, MK. I certainly have been wondering about
 you. Are you OK? I had actually forgotten about
 Sandra by now. I hope she and her family are doing well and the company is what they hoped it would be. Thanks for the kind words, but when I see myself in the mirror, especially in the middle of the night, I wonder who that is. 
Thanks to all. I feel a little better and am finished whining. I called the doctor who did my hysterectomy. As I was talking to the nurse, she actually got on and said, "Hi, this is Michelle, what's going on?' Not many doctors like her. She didn't have time to check my records but she said I probably do not have a cervix. They had me scheduled for a colposcopy here and she said she would do a biopsy. She said she would Make time for me! Even at Christmas. I am going the first week in January. From now on, I should go down there twice a year to see her. She said that it is , at the worst, probably low grade dysplasia at the top of the vagina. I may need to go to the operating room for laser surgery. That didn't sound so bad. At least she, and you all, made me feel better. Thanks. Love and Hugs, and MK, don't stay away so long, Di

Hi Julie, 
Not to worry. I remember my mom telling me that she remembered no pain and she was right. It was hard to move, but NO pain. And yes, you will need a stool softener, but then you will be fine. I had the abdominal also for dysplasia. the possilble beginning of cervical cancer. 
Yes, the flashes are bad, but compared to cancer we can handle them. Silx years later, they are hardly noticeable for me. I'm just warmer than I used to be. I live alone and was just fine with that. I can usually rest better that way. But, I wasn't lucky enougn to have a Hannah. 
In three days, I was able to walk the three houses down the street to get my mail. TAke care of yourself and you are in my prayers. 
Love and Hugs, Di

Posts.Title: Cathi update.....

Posts.Content: I have just read my breastcancer.org that is sent to my email. Connie put it on for me. The new antibody being tested is called pertuzumab, or 2C4. The drug that has had the most testing is an agent that is a pill, and the class of drug is a kinase inhibitor. That drug is called lapatinib. There is data that it is effective in HER2-positive bc that has continued to grow despite Herceptin treatment. Clincal trials are evaluating it in combination with Herceptin, as well as other agents.

Posts.Title: Well I am home from Spokane

Posts.Content:
Hi and Welcome, Nancy.
Where do I start, well my story is somewhat different. You have been getting great advice. I wish I had had this board when I was first diagnosed. 
I had the choice of either and the doctor chose the lumpectomy. We left it up to him. He was wrong. They did MRI's though, and couldn't find any cancer in my breast. It started in the nodes under my arm. Two years later it came back in the breast. . It was probably there in the first place but we will never know. I since have had the mastectomy and more chemo and radiation. I think the now I have the best doctors in the world. I am very blessed to still be OK. Since then, I have had to have surgery due to radiation damage because I had double radiation which they usually just do not do. Now, as a result of this, I can not ever have the reconstruction. Most people never get like this. However, in my case, I could have had the reconstruction if I had had the mastectomy in the first place. However, maybe the chemo the second time was helpful. All I want you to know is that there are several sides to each story. I would definately do what others have said and look at your path report. I have a very aggressive form. Otherwise, the lumpectomy would be ok.
These girls are all so wonderful. Whatever you need to know, someone has been through it. Love and Hugs, DiVanDyke

Posts.Title: Rita, Are you OK?

Posts.Content:
Hi Rita,
I think of you so much! It is just awful to see the pictures of the storm. The mountain looks like it was cut in pieces. I'm so happy to hear from you and know you are ok. I've been worried about your house too. Sometimes the news makes things look even worse. I hope that is the case. 
I Am just fine. I've been gone to see family in Chicago and visit NW Indiana too. Then I had company here. So I'll get back to normal now whatever that is. 
I am see a wonderful physical therapist for my arm. I hadn't moved it for a year and a half and luckily the breast surgeon kicked my _ _ _ and make me do something about it. My shoulder rotated at 0 degrees and we are up to 20 now. It is helping with my lymphadema too. She has taught my a lot. I raise my arm in the air and punch making a fist. 
Then bring it down and open my hand. I do this hourly. We'll see how much it helps and I'll show everyone. Not moving has made the lymphadema worse. 
Love you and keep in touch, Di

Posts.Title: Clutter - a card I got in the mail today

Posts.Content:
Hi MK and Sara,
MK, This is the poem that came with the shawl
Let us pray this blessing of healing
"Please receive this shawl
Curl it around you
Close it over you
Like child's play
And enter into
The warm,dark,quiet
Stillness
There you can rest
Wait for healing
Make friends with time.
Let your body
Breathe in
The secrets of the shawl.
Feel the light
Reach into your bones
Mending,knitting,
Weaving them together
In a new way.
Birthing a new body
Creating a new future."
Rachel Harris from Knitting into the Mystery
 Around our gathered circle(s), this shawl has been passed through our praying hands and been blessed by our loving hearts. 
 
MK, They make shawls for those going through tough times
If you knit, I'll bet you could begin one. We certainly know enough people going through tough times.
 Sara, Let us know when you will be walking so we can think of you. Hugs and love to both, Di

Posts.Title: Vioxx v. Celebrex and Bextra....

Posts.Content:
Hi Holly,
I am also ER-. I sure do understand how you feel. I had a hysterectomy but that was because they found the beginnings of cervical cancer. 
I hate to say this at this time considering the Vioxx thing, but I take 400mg. of Celebrex to prevent another recurrence. That is all that I have. I will continue to take it as long as I can get it. It was recommeded for cancer by Judah Folman a leading cancer researcher. After my recurrence of a 5cm tumor, I am doing well after four years. Doctors say it is a miracle though, and I fully believe that 
Welcome to the board.
I will share anything I can with you. I am leaving for Chicago though and won't be back until Sunday. I may be back on the board before I go though. Hugs, Di
Posts.Title: Stage 2A, Grade 3 tumor, need chemo, radiation but can't take Tamoxifen

Posts.Content:
Hi Stephanie and all,
Oh dear, yes, in my hurry to get out of town I misspelled his name. This information came in an article he wrote about having less chemo at a time over a longer period. He said that if an antiangiogenic drug was not available to take Celabrex, a Cox2 inhibitor to fight inflamation, I believe. That is also why I try to avoid sugar and carbs, it's anti inflamatory, I believe. Many doctors have been giving Celebrex to prevent recurrences. 
Well, it's like everything else. We take the information we have and make the best decision we can. Hugs, Di
